title: Sri Lanka’s national inflation gallops to 21.5-pct in March
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s nation-wide inflation rose 21.5 percent in the 12-months to December 2022, galloping from 17.5 percent a month earlier after two years of money printing under flexible inflation targeting.

The National Consumer Price Index grew from 190.6 percent to 195.2 percent or 2.4 percent in the month of April alone compared to an already wide 4-6 percent target of inflation which the central bank is supposed to generate.

Under ‘flexible inflation targeting’ where the central bank prints money despite collecting reserves (intervening in forex markets to maintain a pegged exchange rate at different levels under ‘flexible’ exchange rates) authorities are able to delay rate hikes at will.
Sri Lanka’s money printing ratcheted up from around February 2020, under so-called ‘developmental state/production economy framework which was said to be similar to Modern Monetary Theory (MMT).
However initial money printing to trigger the current currency crises began around August 2019 under the earlier ‘output gap targeting’ framework which is a milder version of stimulus.
Since July 2019 food prices are up 54.3 percent. (Colombo/Mar22/2022)
